history.content:
I took it in the pilot semester in fall 2019. I really enjoyed it! 

The biggest benefit of the course for me was that it covered topics that were highly relevant to my interests/career plans. These topics were also new and mostly different from all the courses I'd taken before. 

Background: Stats/DS major, CS minor. I've taken most stats upper divs, math110,  cs189, and ee127 (these courses are not necessary for 102 but to give you a sense of where I'm coming from)

The topics covered by 102 seemed like problems that were super relevant to stats/ds industry. They covered topics such as false discovery rate control when you're running many statistical tests over time (a common task for industry data scientists), how to approximate sampling from a distribution without a closed form, Bayesian hierarchal models,  how to choose an plan of action to optimize an unknown reward function, how to ensure privacy in data collection (but with mathematical theory). I had never seen most of these topics before, despite me be stats major. Additionally, there was only a small overlap of topics with cs189 (which was a major concern for most people when this course was first introduced). This was one of the few classes were I was actually excited to go to lecture and learn new and exciting topics and the assignments were interesting and cemented the material. 

Overall, I had a great experience in the course. Two caveats to this:

1) That was the pilot semester, I"m not sure how much it's changed since. Perhaps someone from this semester could weigh in? You can also check out the website

2) Depending on your major, you may have to check reserved seat requirements of whether you can get in. I think it was tight enrollment for these past two semesters.

children.subject: this class is impossible to get in without data science classes and/or if you're not a senior, in case that matters for your background. :(

history.content:
What are people's thoughts on DS102?

Just curious, thinking of taking it.
history.subject: DS102
